headline.main: Study on 'Burn Pits' Cites Inadequate Evidence of Health Effects

docs.abstract: A study released on Monday found that there was insufficient data to conclude that dust and pollution in the war zones of Iraq and Afghanistan could cause long-term health problems in troops.
docs.snippet: A study released on Monday found that there was insufficient data to conclude that dust and pollution in the war zones of Iraq and Afghanistan could cause long-term health problems in troops.

docs.lead_paragraph: For many years, troops returning from Iraq and Afghanistan have complained of breathing problems and some have been found with serious illnesses and diseases. Many doctors and researchers focused on one particular culprit: burn pits used by the military to incinerate everything from plastic water bottles to construction materials.

docs.lead_paragraph: An executive order by the Obama administration offers drug manufacturers and wholesalers a helping hand and a gloved fist in efforts to resolve shortages that have worsened greatly in recent years.

headline.seo: Medicine Shortages Addressed in Obama Executive Order
headline.main: Obama Tries to Speed Response to Shortages in Vital Medicines
headline.print_headline: Obama Tries to Speed Response To Shortages in Vital Medicines

docs.abstract: Pres Obama will issue an executive order that the administration hopes will help resolve a growing number of critical shortages of vital medicines used to treat life-threatening illnesses; order is part of a series of executive orders involving disparate issues that are intended to show that Obama is working to resolve the nation's problems despite a Congress largely paralyzed by partisanship.
docs.snippet: An executive order by the Obama administration offers drug manufacturers and wholesalers a helping hand and a gloved fist in efforts to resolve shortages that have worsened greatly in recent years.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ten years after anthrax attacks, biodefense is busted.

headline.seo: How Ready Are We for Bioterrorism?
headline.main: How Ready Are We for Bioterrorism?
headline.print_headline: Warning: There's Not Nearly Enough Of This Vaccine To Go Around

docs.abstract: National security officials in both the Bush and Obama administrations have consistently placed biodefense at or near the top of the national-security agenda and have warned of the extreme likelihood of a biological attack since 2001; biodefense experts warn that despite this broad agreement on the nature and likelihood of a biological attack, the United States is woefully unprepared for an attack of this nature.
docs.snippet: Ten years after anthrax attacks, biodefense is busted.

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject

keywords.value: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: If you have heard it once, you have heard it hundreds of times. ''The United States spends too much on health care.'' This is not a partisan point. You can hear this from Republicans as well as Democrats. ''We know that our families, our economy and our nation itself will not succeed in the 21st century if we continue to be held down by the weight of rapidly rising health care costs,'' President Obama said in 2009. Representative Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin, agrees: ''There is no serious dispute - on either side of the aisle.'' Unfortunately, few people really understand how much we spend on health care, how much we need to spend to provide quality care, and the difference between the two. Do we spend too much? Would cutting costs require rationing, or worse, death panels?
